feed.title: mark o’brien
feed.subtitle: A place where little thoughts becomes big ideas at the intersection of leadership, ethics, technology, culture, politics, science, mathematics, language and philosophy.

entry.title: First Example Post
entry.content:
Ok, so, this is a first passage which just has a bunch of text but which is also meant to show the use of footnotes.1 And I don’t think this will be super special but definitely keen to see how it does look.

And this is more text with lots of blah blah but also has a second footnote that is worth noting.2

References

  1. Jobin, Anna, Marcello Ienca, and Effy Vayena. “The global landscape of AI ethics guidelines.” Nature Machine Intelligence 1, no. 9 (2019): 389-399. ↩

  2. Binder, Matt (March 3, 2022). “Why is Randi Zuckerberg making cringe music videos about cryptocurrency?” Mashable. ↩
entry.summary: Ok, so, this is a first passage which just has a bunch of text but which is also meant to show the use of footnotes.1 And I don’t think this will be super special but definitely keen to see how it does look. Jobin, Anna, Marcello Ienca, and Effy Vayena. “The global landscape of AI ethics guidelines.” Nature Machine Intelligence 1, no. 9 (2019): 389-399. ↩

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
